<font size="3">

For more info, see here:  
[https://scikit-learn.org/stable/datasets/toy_dataset.html?highlight=boston#diabetes-dataset](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/datasets/toy_dataset.html?highlight=boston#diabetes-dataset){target="_blank"}

The **diabetes dataset** is loaded using `load_diabetes()`. This
returns a 'Bunch' object with the following keys:

| Key | Description |
|-----|-------------------------------------------------------------|
| `DESCR` | Description of the dataset |
| `data_filename` | Location of the CSV file containing the data being imported |
| `target_filename` | Location of the CSV file containing the target data being imported |
| `feature_names` | Names of the 10 groups of data |
| `data` | The 442 data points in each of the 10 groups of data, formatted as a 442x10 array |
| `target` | The target data, namely a quantitative measure of disease progression one year after baseline |

```{python}
from sklearn.datasets import load_diabetes

# Load the dataset
diabetes = load_diabetes()

# Show the dataset's keys
print(list(diabetes))
```

```{python}
# Description of the dataset
print(diabetes['DESCR'])
```

```{python}
# Location of the CSV file containing the data being imported
print(diabetes['data_filename'])
```

```{python}
# Location of the CSV file containing the target data being imported
print(diabetes['target_filename'])
```

```{python}
# Names of the 10 groups of data
print(diabetes['feature_names'])
```

```{python}
# The 442 data points in each of the 10 groups of data, formatted as a 442x10 array
print(diabetes['data'])
```

```{python}
# The target data, namely a quantitative measure of disease progression one
# year after baseline
print(diabetes['target'][:20])
```

The groups of data can be plotted against each other or against the target
group as follows:

```{python}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# PLOT
plt.scatter(diabetes['data'][:, 6], diabetes['target'])
plt.title('Diabetes dataset')
x = diabetes['feature_names'][6]
plt.xlabel(x + ' (hdl, high-density lipoproteins)')
plt.ylabel('Disease progression one year after baseline')
plt.show()
```

The data is much easier to work with if it is converted to a data frame:

```{python}
import pandas as pd

# CONVERT TO DATA FRAME
diabetes_df = pd.DataFrame(diabetes['data'], columns=diabetes['feature_names'])
diabetes_df['Y'] = diabetes['target']

# PLOT
plt.scatter(diabetes_df['bp'], diabetes_df['Y'])
plt.title('Diabetes dataset')
plt.xlabel('bp (average blood pressure)')
plt.ylabel('Disease progression one year after baseline')
plt.show()
```
